Pirate Yakuza reminds me why I love this series. Beneath the over the top action, absurd and funny moments, it has its heart rooted firmly on reality. It explores life as a whole: bits of absurd, bits of funny, some parts intense and other parts heartwarming while can still be sad. It's a mix of those feelings that is the heart of the series and while at first glance Pirate Yakuza is the most absurd canon spin off/side story in the series with pirates and chasing after legendary treasure, it still focuses on human relationships and dreams handled with sensitivity and care. 

Narrative wise, while this game's Chapter 2 has its quality dips with its pacing slowed to a halt, especially after its stellar prologue. The pacing recovers well from Chapter 3 onwards with great character developments all throughout the story. The genius in Pirate Yakuza's narrative is it uses Majima as an unreliable narrator; narrating his story as an amnesiac turned pirate chasing legendary treasure and elixir of life. You know things definitely happened, but the details are not clear since the story is from Majima's POV and it fits his persona as the Mad Dog. That plot device is still used in the after credit that it even recontextualize the whole story into a tale of someone wanting to bring hope to a hospitalized friend, that friend is obviously Kiryu who is in hospital after what happened in Infiite Wealth. It's handled with such care that I personally find it so touching, much more so because I have a family member who is also fighting an illness.

The actual pirate story is filled with great characters who develop throughout the story with their own motives and personalities often bring tensions around each others. While the villain could've had more screentime to give him more depth, I know why RGG focuses more on the other characters like Noah, Masaru, Saejima, etc. Because of Pirate Yakuza's tone is more fairy tale since it is essentially told by Majima, the conflict between Majima and the villain is much more clearly defined like good vs evil. I think this simpler conflict fits the game's tone and what it's trying to say, though I understand if people expect more depth for the conflict similar to the other entries in the series. Overall though, it's a good story of Majima helping repay a kid for saving his life by trying to achieve the kid's dream. It is well written, straightforward and also heartwarming while still having bits of conflicts from secondary villains and other supporting characters that add depth to the story.

Gameplay wise, compared to Kiryu's Gaiden game which plays much more like a mainline Yakuza game, Pirate Yakuza is much more experimental and takes more advantage at being a spin off/side story game. As much as I love Kiryu's Gaiden, that game's spy thriller aspect doesn't translate to its gameplay while Pirate Yakuza has a fully fuctional pirate ship to control, building your crews and ships, etc. It plays both like a Yakuza game and a pirate game which it delivers on both aspects. As such it is experimental by design and I appreciate it. The combat feels a bit different with Majima having a jump that he can use to either dodge or aerial combo while the ship combat feels good with quite limited but distinct choice of weapons to choose. Both combat modes feel good to play and Mad Dog fighting style in this game is my favorite iteration of Majima's styles. Combining Thug and Mad Dog into 1 style is such a great idea and the moveset feels so fitting for majima as a character and plays great mechanically. Sea Dog style is also equally good to use with its sidearms that are much more seamless to use than Gaiden's Agent style's gadgets. Also the implementation of equipments in the form of rings that are visible on Majima's fingers is cool. Some of the rings also alter the combat like having the mad dog style much more faster or the boomerang sidearm to last longer are great although there's too many rings that increase attack power. These games are not hard and there's already permanent skills to upgrade attack power so having many rings that increase attack power is just too much (although there's a mod that makes the rings to not increase attack power).

Also quite unexpectedly, Pirate Yakuza is the only RGG game that has issues with NVIDIA DLSS. I encountered missing visual/black screen a couple times when using DLSS. I had no such issues with any other RGG games and there's a couple times where the fps is not stable. Apart from Yakuza 6 which was the first Dragon Engine game so that game was understandable to have technical issues, Pirate Yakuza is the one with similar technical issues which is unfortunate since the game looks great and often run great too.

Overall, personally I feel like Pirate Yakuza is RGG unflitered. This game is just the devs having fun with the gameplay aspects and just want to tell a story the way they want without a burden to impress anyone and for me personally, it's great. It's such a good feeling to play an entry in a long running series that dares to do something different, it even has two musical notes in the game which are hilarious and then the story concludes in one of the most touching bromance scene. This is precisely why I love this series. Despite some of the experiments in this game fails a bit like the story's uneven pacing in chapter 2, the final villain lacking more depth, the hitbox from gun sidearm is sometimes not functioning properly and technical issues, it still delivers on telling a sincere human drama with a much more hopeful tone, which is a great decision due to the previous entries often end on bittersweet endings.

Pirate Yakuza shines and sinks.

Villains feel ramshackle and poorly paced, and the more interesting aspects of the story are all too often briefly touched on before being left abandoned. 

The gameplay is a mixed bag, as well. The presence of side stories alone raises the category above Gaiden, and their quality is solid to good, but Honolulu feels even more empty than in Infinite Wealth. If RGG is going to keep coming back to this setting, it needs to be revised and elevated; it needs to have the same level of detail Kamurocho, Sotenbori, and Ijincho have in abundance. Combat is fun as a gimmick, but neither combat style has depth to match its panache, and far, far too many fights amount to the Yakuza 6 textbook of throwing tons and tons of guys at you. 

I really think Gaiden's price point of $50 would suit Pirate Yakuza better, but if you're enthusiastic about pirates or the Yakuza franchise, $60 still does garner a recommendation from me, albeit one more tacit than I've made for RGG's games in recent years.

It took me a while to finish this game, not because it was difficult, but because I’m a 100% completionist when it comes to RGG Studio titles. I wasn’t rushing through the main story; instead, I made it a point to complete every side story and mini-game before touching the final chapters. That’s just how I enjoy these games.

The story missions themselves are fun and engaging. The narrative has its moments, and while it didn’t blow me away, I liked the ending and appreciated the teaser for the next Yakuza entry. It left me curious about what’s coming next.

Combat-wise, it’s solid but a bit repetitive. The heat actions are cool and flashy, but it’s always off-putting how everyone else disappears during them except for the enemy you’re targeting. Then they just reappear like nothing happened, which breaks the immersion. It’s also strange that characters use swords, knives, guns, and even hooks, yet there’s no real visual damage—just some slash marks and fake blood splats that enemies shake off like it’s nothing. It feels disconnected from the intensity of the weapons being used. That said, the two new fighting styles are distinct and add some welcome variety.

The battleship gameplay was a mixed bag. It was fun in concept, but the equipment system felt unbalanced. Min-maxing wasn’t satisfying. I just slapped the strongest weapons—laser cannons, rocket launchers, and miniguns—on both sides and steamrolled everything. There wasn’t much incentive to experiment with different loadouts when the most powerful gear made everything else obsolete.

Overall, it’s a good time, especially if you’re into the Yakuza formula. It’s not perfect, but it’s packed with charm, side content, and that signature RGG flavor. If you’re a fan of the series, you’ll find plenty to enjoy here. I'd say this is way better like a dragon entry than the Like A Dragon: Ishin! game they release a while back ago. I have plat'd every game in the Yakuza series twice minus Ishin, originally on PS and then again when I transferred my gaming library to PC, and this game is now tied for the last place with the aforementioned Ishin spinoff. 

To keep an otherwise lengthy review short, this game fails for me on two main aspects - the combat and the story.

I played this game on Professional difficulty, and the combat is tied with samurai Yakuza and Yakuza 3 for the worst. Y3 on legend was frustrating because the AI just blocks all day, and Ishin was janky, like every input registers a frame late and an atrocious camera. This game's combat is terrible because I felt like I was playing Dynasty Warriors. You just button mash to win, and sometimes you have to button mash because some idiot at RGG decided to have you fight huge mobs just like in DW, but since the screen becomes all cluttered with friend and foe that blocks vision of what you character model is doing, you just smash buttons and hope it works out instead of inputting deliberate combos. Then, to add oil to fire, they decided to add a jump to this game. I cannot tell you how many times I wanted to sprint, but only ended up jumping in place, or how many times my combos got messed up because I accidentally jumped.

In terms of the story, it felt really inconsequential. In Gaiden, which was also a ".5" game, you actually felt the relationship build between Kiryu and Hanawa, and the final payoff with an emotional Kiryu at the end of the game made it so you went on a journey with a purpose. In this game, I didn't care for any one. There were too many allies in this short game to actually build a relationship with, and the enemies literally just phase in and out like a rotating roulette of villains. At the end of the game, nothing has really changed for Majima. The sad thing is, some of the characters could've really had potential. Naomi (and her interactions with Saejima) comes to mind. At this point, it should be clear that RGG don't know what to do with female characters aside from using them as plot devices.

Also, a personal "wtf" moment  - somehow you're tasked with chasing down the bad, evil Devil Flags for stealing someone else's treasure as a righteous hero, but then you go and steal Esperanza's treasure that belongs to the Nele islanders? 

For a long time player of the series, this game was a poor effort, but if you come into it with no expectations, and no frame of reference, then this could be a buy-on-sale game to try.

Pile on top the sheer number of battles thrown at you to pad out the game's length and you have the perfect recipe for tedium. It get's old very fast, and as the story slowly drags itself along, requiring you to go to A to B and back to A just for the heck of it, you really start to question what makes this experience worth it.

I have plat'd every game in the Yakuza series twice minus Ishin, originally on PS and then again when I transferred my gaming library to PC, and this game is now tied for the last place with the aforementioned Ishin spinoff. 

To keep an otherwise lengthy review short, this game fails for me on two main aspects - the combat and the story.

I played this game on Professional difficulty, and the combat is tied with samurai Yakuza and Yakuza 3 for the worst. Y3 on legend was frustrating because the AI just blocks all day, and Ishin was janky, like every input registers a frame late and an atrocious camera. This game's combat is terrible because I felt like I was playing Dynasty Warriors. You just button mash to win, and sometimes you have to button mash because some idiot at RGG decided to have you fight huge mobs just like in DW, but since the screen becomes all cluttered with friend and foe that blocks vision of what you character model is doing, you just smash buttons and hope it works out instead of inputting deliberate combos. Then, to add oil to fire, they decided to add a jump to this game. I cannot tell you how many times I wanted to sprint, but only ended up jumping in place, or how many times my combos got messed up because I accidentally jumped.

In terms of the story, it felt really inconsequential. In Gaiden, which was also a ".5" game, you actually felt the relationship build between Kiryu and Hanawa, and the final payoff with an emotional Kiryu at the end of the game made it so you went on a journey with a purpose. In this game, I didn't care for any one. There were too many allies in this short game to actually build a relationship with, and the enemies literally just phase in and out like a rotating roulette of villains. At the end of the game, nothing has really changed for Majima. The sad thing is, some of the characters could've really had potential. Naomi (and her interactions with Saejima) comes to mind. At this point, it should be clear that RGG don't know what to do with female characters aside from using them as plot devices.

Also, a personal "wtf" moment  - somehow you're tasked with chasing down the bad, evil Devil Flags for stealing someone else's treasure as a righteous hero, but then you go and steal Esperanza's treasure that belongs to the Nele islanders? 

For a long time player of the series, this game was a poor effort, but if you come into it with no expectations, and no frame of reference, then this could be a buy-on-sale game to try.

I have plat'd every game in the Yakuza series twice minus Ishin, originally on PS and then again when I transferred my gaming library to PC, and this game is now tied for the last place with the aforementioned Ishin spinoff. 

To keep an otherwise lengthy review short, this game fails for me on two main aspects - the combat and the story.

I played this game on Professional difficulty, and the combat is tied with samurai Yakuza and Yakuza 3 for the worst. Y3 on legend was frustrating because the AI just blocks all day, and Ishin was janky, like every input registers a frame late and an atrocious camera. This game's combat is terrible because I felt like I was playing Dynasty Warriors. You just button mash to win, and sometimes you have to button mash because some idiot at RGG decided to have you fight huge mobs just like in DW, but since the screen becomes all cluttered with friend and foe that blocks vision of what you character model is doing, you just smash buttons and hope it works out instead of inputting deliberate combos. Then, to add oil to fire, they decided to add a jump to this game. I cannot tell you how many times I wanted to sprint, but only ended up jumping in place, or how many times my combos got messed up because I accidentally jumped.

In terms of the story, it felt really inconsequential. In Gaiden, which was also a ".5" game, you actually felt the relationship build between Kiryu and Hanawa, and the final payoff with an emotional Kiryu at the end of the game made it so you went on a journey with a purpose. In this game, I didn't care for any one. There were too many allies in this short game to actually build a relationship with, and the enemies literally just phase in and out like a rotating roulette of villains. At the end of the game, nothing has really changed for Majima. The sad thing is, some of the characters could've really had potential. Naomi (and her interactions with Saejima) comes to mind. At this point, it should be clear that RGG don't know what to do with female characters aside from using them as plot devices.

Also, a personal "wtf" moment  - somehow you're tasked with chasing down the bad, evil Devil Flags for stealing someone else's treasure as a righteous hero, but then you go and steal Esperanza's treasure that belongs to the Nele islanders? 

For a long time player of the series, this game was a poor effort, but if you come into it with no expectations, and no frame of reference, then this could be a buy-on-sale game to try.
